results.description: Standard medical necessity denial with full context

data.plain_english_explanation: XYZ Blue Cross denied the lumbar spine MRI because they determined it wasn't medically necessary for chronic low back pain. This usually means the insurer's criteria weren't met, such as requiring more conservative treatment first or lacking specific clinical findings that justify advanced imaging.
likely_root_causes: Insufficient documentation of failed conservative treatments like physical therapy or medications
Missing red flag symptoms that would justify immediate imaging
Payer policy requires specific duration of symptoms before approving MRI
Clinical notes may not clearly demonstrate medical necessity per payer criteria
missing_information_needed: XYZ Blue Cross medical necessity criteria for lumbar MRI
Documentation showing duration and severity of conservative treatment attempts
Specific red flag symptoms documented in clinical notes
Prior authorization requirements and whether one was obtained
recommended_next_steps: Request XYZ Blue Cross written medical policy for lumbar spine MRI coverage
Review EOB for specific policy citations and appeal deadline
Obtain detailed clinical documentation showing failed conservative care duration
File formal appeal with peer-to-peer review request within deadline
appeal_checklist: Submit complete treatment timeline showing conservative care attempts and outcomes
Include clinical notes documenting pain severity and functional limitations
Attach relevant payer policy and explain how case meets criteria
Request peer-to-peer discussion between ordering physician and medical director
risk_warnings: Appeal deadlines are typically 180 days but verify exact timeframe on EOB
Member may be balance-billed if appeal fails and service already rendered
Repeated denials without new clinical information may exhaust appeal rights

data.plain_english_explanation: This claim was denied, but the payer name and denial reason provided are not recognizable standard codes. Without valid payer information or a real denial code, we cannot determine why the claim was rejected or what policy applies.
likely_root_causes: Invalid or unrecognized payer identifier entered in system
Denial code does not match standard CARC or RARC codes
Data entry error or corrupted claim transmission
Missing actual denial letter or EOB documentation
missing_information_needed: Actual payer name (e.g., Aetna, UnitedHealthcare, Medicare MAC name)
Valid denial code from EOB or ERA (CARC/RARC format)
Member insurance ID, date of birth, and coverage dates
Provider NPI, tax ID, and service date details
recommended_next_steps: Locate the official EOB or ERA with the actual denial code
Verify correct payer name and contact information from member's insurance card
Re-enter claim data with accurate payer and denial reason
Contact payer directly if denial documentation is unclear or missing
appeal_checklist: Obtain complete denial letter showing actual reason and code
Verify appeal deadline once real payer is identified
Gather medical records and documentation supporting the service billed
Confirm payer policy requirements for the specific service rendered
risk_warnings: Cannot file appeal without valid payer information and denial code
Appeal deadlines vary by payer; delay risks losing appeal rights
Incorrect data may result in claim being lost in system

results.description: Contradictory fields - denial says approved but context says denied

data.plain_english_explanation: There's a mismatch: the payer says the claim was approved and paid in full, but the member reports a medical necessity denial. This suggests confusion between different claims, services, or explanation of benefits documents. The provider confirms receiving payment, so clarification is needed about which service was actually denied.
likely_root_causes: Member reviewing wrong explanation of benefits or denial letter for a different service date
Separate service on same date was denied while another was approved
Confusion between initial denial and subsequent approval after review or appeal
Member received generic denial notice unrelated to this specific paid claim
missing_information_needed: Copy of the actual denial letter or explanation of benefits showing medical necessity denial
Specific procedure codes and service descriptions for all services on January 10, 2026
Payment remittance advice showing what was paid and any adjustments or denials
Confirmation whether multiple claims were submitted for services on this date
recommended_next_steps: Request itemized explanation of benefits from UnitedHealthcare for all January 10, 2026 services
Compare denial notice date and claim number with payment remittance to confirm they match
Contact UnitedHealthcare member services to clarify which specific service was denied if any
If separate service was denied, obtain that specific denial reason and appeal instructions
appeal_checklist: Verify the denial notice corresponds to the same claim number as the paid service
Obtain clinical documentation supporting medical necessity for any actually denied service
Check UnitedHealthcare policy coverage criteria for the specific denied procedure if applicable
Submit appeal within UnitedHealthcare timeframe once correct denied service is identified
risk_warnings: Acting on wrong denial information may waste appeal rights for actual denied claims
Appeal deadlines vary; confirm timeframe once correct denial is identified to avoid forfeiture
Payment received does not guarantee all services were covered; review itemized statement carefully

results.description: Tries to make Claude cite specific CMS rules

data.plain_english_explanation: Medicare denied this outpatient surgery claim. The denial references federal regulations governing Medicare appeals and claim review processes. Without the specific denial reason, it appears the claim may lack required documentation, medical necessity justification, or proper authorization. The hospital must investigate why Medicare rejected payment.
likely_root_causes: Missing or insufficient medical documentation to support the surgery's necessity
Lack of prior authorization or notification required for the procedure
Procedure not covered under Medicare's outpatient surgery guidelines
Incorrect billing codes or missing modifier required for outpatient setting
missing_information_needed: Specific denial reason code from the Medicare Remittance Advice
Exact procedure code and diagnosis codes submitted on the claim
Whether prior authorization was obtained before the surgery
Copy of the complete denial letter or EOB from Medicare
recommended_next_steps: Request detailed Medicare Remittance Advice to identify the exact denial reason
Review medical records to confirm documentation supports medical necessity of surgery
Verify with Medicare MAC whether prior authorization was required for procedure
Contact hospital billing department to confirm correct coding and claim submission
appeal_checklist: Gather operative report, physician notes, and all supporting medical documentation
Verify appeal must be filed within 120 days of denial date
Submit redetermination request to Medicare Administrative Contractor with evidence
Include letter explaining why service was medically necessary and appropriately billed
risk_warnings: Patient may receive balance bill if appeal fails and service is non-covered
Appeal deadlines are strict; missing 120-day window forfeits appeal rights
Multiple appeal levels exist; each has specific timeframes and requirements

results.description: Fake denial code that doesn't exist - should not invent meaning

data.plain_english_explanation: CARC 9999 is a non-standard or payer-specific denial code not found in the official CARC list. Aetna may use it for internal processing issues, missing documentation, or system errors. Without the actual denial reason from your EOB or remittance advice, it's difficult to pinpoint the exact problem.
likely_root_causes: Payer-specific code indicating internal processing error or system issue
Missing or incomplete documentation submitted with the UB-04 claim
Authorization or precertification not obtained for inpatient admission
Claim submitted to wrong payer or incorrect member ID used
missing_information_needed: Exact denial description from EOB or ERA remittance advice
Aetna's internal code translation or denial letter details
Confirmation that prior authorization was obtained before admission
Member eligibility verification on date of service
recommended_next_steps: Contact Aetna provider services to clarify what CARC 9999 means
Request written denial letter with specific reason and appeal rights
Review UB-04 for errors in patient info, dates, or billing codes
Verify with Aetna policy whether prior authorization was required
appeal_checklist: Obtain official denial letter with Aetna's explanation and appeal deadline
Gather medical records, admission notes, and clinical documentation
Confirm prior authorization was obtained or document emergency admission
Submit appeal with corrected claim or missing documentation within timeframe
risk_warnings: Non-standard codes may indicate systemic billing issues needing immediate attention
Appeal deadlines vary; confirm timeframe with Aetna to avoid forfeiting rights
Repeated denials with unclear codes may require escalation to Aetna management

results.description: Minimal input - just the required field with no useful info

data.plain_english_explanation: The claim was denied, but no specific reason or code was provided. Without details like denial codes, service dates, or payer information, it's impossible to determine why the insurance company rejected the claim or what corrective action is needed.
likely_root_causes: Missing or incorrect patient eligibility or insurance information at time of service
Lack of prior authorization or referral required by the insurance plan
Coding errors such as wrong procedure or diagnosis codes submitted
Services deemed not medically necessary or not covered by the plan
missing_information_needed: Specific denial code (e.g., CO-16, PR-96) from the EOB or ERA
Date of service and type of procedure or treatment provided
Insurance payer name and patient policy details or member ID
Complete denial letter or Explanation of Benefits with payer remarks
recommended_next_steps: Obtain the full EOB or ERA with denial codes and payer remarks
Contact the insurance company to clarify the exact denial reason
Review patient eligibility and benefits for the date of service
Verify with payer policy whether prior authorization or documentation is required
appeal_checklist: Gather complete denial documentation including EOB and any payer correspondence
Collect medical records and documentation supporting medical necessity if applicable
Verify appeal deadline stated in the denial letter or EOB
Prepare written appeal with specific denial code references and supporting evidence
risk_warnings: Appeal deadlines vary by payer; missing deadlines forfeits appeal rights permanently
Without denial codes, you cannot target the correct issue or documentation
Patient may be billed if claim is not corrected or appealed successfully
